summary: Since 1789, the U.S. government’s drawback program has encouraged manufacturing and exports by refunding certain customs duties. For example, a merchant who paid duties on imported fabric, made it into clothes, and then exported the clothes could claim a refund for import duties paid. The program refunds about $1 billion a year. We found problems in how CBP checks these claims. For example, CBP’s new...
title: Customs and Border Protection: Risk Management for Tariff Refunds Should Be Improved
